raw_text:
Glasgow hosts tsunami benefit gig
 
 The top names in Scottish music are taking part in a benefit concert in aid of the victims of the Asian tsunami.
 
 All 10,000 tickets for Saturday's concert, featuring Franz Ferdinand, Belle and Sebastian and Travis, at Glasgow's SECC sold out in 36 hours. Mull Historical Society, Deacon Blue, Idlewild, Texas, Mogwai and Teenage Fanclub are among the other acts performing at the concert. Organisers hope to raise at least £250,000 from the show.
 
 It follows a Cardiff gig starring Eric Clapton, Keane and Jools Holland, which raised more than £1.25m. And it is taking place on the same night as a tsunami benefit show in Bristol, which will see Massive Attack and Portishead share a stage for the first time. Colin MacIntyre, of Mull Historical Society, was playing another gig on the same day but said he was determined to make the Glasgow benefit. He said: "I think we were all affected by seeing the reports coming from the Far East. "We all know somebody who was there, but more than that it was that we had never seen a wave of destruction, a natural disaster, like this in my generation. "I'm lucky as an artist to be able to perform at something like this."
llama3.2:1b: Glasgow hosts benefit concert for tsunami victims featuring top Scottish musicians and raising money for aid efforts.
The event, held on the same night as another tsunami benefit show in Bristol, features bands such as Franz Ferdinand, Belle and Sebastian, and Travis.
Tickets sold out in 36 hours, with an estimated £250,000 raised from the Glasgow concert.
llama3.2:3b: Glasgow hosts a tsunami benefit concert featuring Franz Ferdinand, Belle and Sebastian, Travis, and other Scottish musicians, with 10,000 tickets sold out in 36 hours.

The event aims to raise £250,000 for victims of the Asian tsunami, following a similar benefit show in Cardiff that raised over £1.25m on the same night, as well as another benefit concert planned for Bristol featuring Massive Attack and Portishead.

The event featured Franz Ferdinand, Belle and Sebastian, Travis, as well as a number of other Scottish musical acts, including Mull Historical Society, Deacon Blue, Idlewild, Texas, Mogwai and Teenage Fanclub.
This concert follows similar efforts in Cardiff and Bristol.
Colin MacIntyre made the decision to participate despite performing elsewhere on the same night.

The event aims to raise at least £250,000.
Similar benefit gigs took place in Cardiff and Bristol raising over £1.25m and featuring Massive Attack and Portishead respectively.
Colin MacIntyre from Mull Historical Society participated due to shared emotional impact of the disaster.

deepseek-r1:1.5b: Glasgow is hosting a tsunami benefit concert for Scottish music stars, with performances featuring Franz Ferdinand, Belle, Sebastian, Travis, Mull Historical Society, Deacon Blue, Idlewild, Texas, Mogwai, and Teenage Fanclub.

tinyllama:1.1b: Glasgow hosts a benefit concert featuring top names in Scottish music, including Franz Ferdinand, Belle and Sebastian, Travis, Mulli Historical Society (MHS), Deacon Blue, Idlewið, Texas, Moogwai & Teena Ge FaNCubo.
The show is part of the ongoing fundraising effort for victims of the Asian tsunaim disaster.
MHS will perform in tandem with other notable artists such as Eric Clapton, Keane, Joools Holland, and Portishead.
The Glasgow benefit is taking place on the same night as a Bristol show that saw Massive Attack and Portishead share a stage for the first time.
MHS member Colin MacIntyre said he wanted to make the Scottish event and was determined to ensure it went well despite the natural disaster in Japan.
He shared his thoughts about witnessing the aftermath of the disaster, saying "I feel lucky as an artist because we can perform, but I'm also lucky that my family is safe."
tinydolphin:1.1b: The tsunami benefit gig in Glasgow is being hosted by the top names in Scottish music, including Franz Ferdinand, Belle and Sebastian, Travis, Mogwai, and Teenage Fanclub.
The event will take place on Saturday, February 10th, and tickets have already sold out in just three days.
Organizers hope to raise at least £250,000 from the show, with an additional benefit concert taking place in Bristol on the same night featuring Massive Attack and Portishead.
Colin MacIntyre of Mull Historical Society was playing another gig on February 1st but felt compelled to participate in the Glasgow benefit due to the devastation caused by the tsunami.
He emphasized that he hopes others will join him, noting that it's "not just about saving money for the charity, but also showcasing our talent and unity in this situation."
